To improve, students would benefit from more practice problems focusing on vector operations and TopHat exercises to enhance their familiarity with the platform.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to various problems, particularly pulley systems, engaging and thought-provoking. They appreciated the "recipe" for drawing FBDs and the insight that forces can be resolved into components. The concept of changing the system or coordinate axes to simplify calculations was also intriguing. Students enjoyed the practical problems, especially those involving pulleys and ice, which challenged their understanding and encouraged collaboration.
input:
The different applications of FBD to solve problems like the example of the man supporting himself on the pulley system. 
We had one of the same problems with two people pulling a rope on each side and the tension in the rope is between both of their forces
Despite this being a difficult concept, i though the man pulling himself up with a pulley was very interesting, as it shows how pulleys can be utilized in industry 
top hat
I found the fact that forces had resisting components interesting. 
drawing free body diagrams to set up equations
I found the fact that it became 2T interesting when he pulled himself up.
The “recipe” for free body diagrams. It made drawing them a lot easier.
I found it most interesting that to hold yourself still while on a pulley system, you only need to apply the force of half your weight. 
Today, I found the conceptual problem with the man pulling up with a velocity the most interesting. If you had done the problem in your mind, then you would have gotten twice the answer. 
 The pulley system/elevator problems because I find them very fun to do.
 I found the top hat questions about normal force to be most interesting 
 Top hat question where the man on the chair pulls on the rope. I thought it was an interesting real life problem to solve.
 The part that I found most interesting about today's lecture was the conceptual questions because they were tricky.
 I found the first example with the man in the chair the most interesting.  The fact that he only has to pull with half the force of gravity was intriguing. 
 free body diagrams

 I thought learning how to draw free body diagrams was interesting. I also thought that learning about how the axes can be rotated so that more of the forces line up with them was really useful and interesting. 
 three block problem

 You can turn external forces into internal forces 
 Break out room problems involving free body diagrams and work
 I find tension interesting. The fact that two things can way down one rope and it's the same tension fascinated me.

 Free body diagrams and how acceleration works

 That pulley systems make it easier to lift things up

 Understanding my mistakes after he went over one of the questions on top hat
 the use of free bodies to solve the atwood machine problem with forces

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of two blocks and forces challenging, with several expressing confusion about problems involving stacked blocks, especially when one or both were on frictionless surfaces. The conceptual difference between push and pull forces, and the application of friction coefficients were also areas of difficulty. Some students struggled with determining which forces to include in free body diagrams and rearranging equations. A few found the final problem of the lecture particularly confusing. Students appreciated the interactive lectures and exam question examples, but some wished for more time to be spent on conceptual questions and problem-solving.
input:
Friction on an incline was what confused me. When more than one or two forces are applied, I feel like things are bound to get confusing. 
I found the top hat question about the two blocks hanging from the pulley the most confusing just because I understood it when I set the tensions equal to each other but not conceptually 
stacked bodys
Figuring out all the different forces that go with boxes next to each other together 
Everything was clear, just the problem with the bottom block accelerating was hard
I didn't find any of the material confusing or unclear, good lecture today
The last example with two blocks and one sliding on the other was confusing 
I was confused by the question with the two blocks where the bottom block had no friction. 
Sometimes finding the force needed to move a block, but this was typically for more complicated problems.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Specify the confusion with multiple blocks:** Instead of a general statement about multiple blocks, highlight the specific confusion with blocks on top of each other or blocks with varying coefficients of friction. This makes the summary more focused and actionable. For example, "Students found it particularly challenging to apply friction concepts when blocks were stacked on top of each other or had varying coefficients of friction."

2. **Clarify the confusion with the last top hat question:** Instead of just mentioning it was confusing, specify what exactly students found confusing. This could be the combination of free body diagrams, determining forces, or the concept of combining masses into one system. For instance, "Many students were confused by the last top hat question involving two blocks with different masses, specifically in combining free body diagrams and determining forces."

3. **Combine similar topics:** Group related topics together to make the summary more concise. For example, combine the confusion about the difference between static and kinetic friction with the difficulty in understanding the purpose of fs_max. "Students struggled to differentiate between static and kinetic friction and understand the practical application of the maximum static friction (fs_max) in real-world scenarios."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with understanding friction, particularly in complex scenarios involving multiple blocks. They found it challenging to apply friction concepts when blocks were stacked on top of each other or had varying coefficients of friction. Many students were confused by the last top hat question involving two blocks with different masses, specifically in combining free body diagrams and determining forces. Some sought clarification on the unitless coefficient of friction and how to reliably create equivalent, easier-to-solve problems and diagrams.

Several students struggled with the last problem of the lecture, involving two blocks with one sliding on the other, due to its complexity and the need to consider multiple systems. Some students sought clarification on when to use specific formulas, how to rearrange equations, and the difference between static and kinetic friction. A few students also expressed a desire for more practice problems and exam questions to better understand and apply FBDs.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students encountered challenges applying Free Body Diagrams (FBDs), particularly in complex scenarios such as blocks on inclines, blocks stacked on top of each other with varying friction, and blocks sliding on one another. The last problem involving two blocks with one sliding on the other was notably confusing due to the necessity of considering multiple systems. To improve understanding and application of FBDs, students emphasized the need for more practice problems and exam questions. Additionally, students sought clarification on when to use specific formulas, how to rearrange equations, and the distinction between static and kinetic friction to better grasp these concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat questions engaging and helpful in solidifying their understanding of concepts like tension, reference frames, and Newton's laws. The interactive nature of these questions, such as the spaceship and tug-of-war scenarios, allowed students to apply their knowledge in imaginative and relatable contexts. The variety of questions, including conceptual and problem-based ones, catered to different learning styles and gauged students' comprehension effectively. Some students noted that the time allocated for these questions could be slightly increased to allow for more thorough discussion and understanding. Overall, the Top Hat questions were a popular and valuable component of the lecture.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of centripetal force challenging and desired more clarification, particularly regarding why the acceleration vector points inwards and how each variable impacts the overall equation for drag force. The application of centripetal force in various scenarios, such as a skydiver entering water and objects moving in circular paths, also caused confusion. Some students struggled with the transition between different substances and understanding when terminal velocity begins and ends. Additionally, students sought more examples and in-depth explanations, especially for deriving equations and applying concepts to three-dimensional free body diagrams.
input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities. 
 What was confusing about this lecture was what forces can be considered a centripetal force.  I saw that soletimes it can be the normal force or some other force.
 Circular motion/centripetal force caused by friction
 The example involving the acceleration and drag force on the jumper in the ocean.
 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.
 I felt that the first group problem was confusing but once we went over it I understood it better 
 I don't get how velocity changes when you switch between materials.
 Not too confused, just a bit worried about the exam next week.
 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously 
 circular motion was barely even taught, especially the net force portion 
 On the first top hat group question finding the equation and what cancelled out 
 I think more explanation should be there for the top hat examples. I was confused at a few steps.
 Normal force on the top of a hill
 I thought the last two top hat questions were confusing 
 Trying to solve a problem with very to no numbers given and having to figure out the algebra and forces 
 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute
 Figuring out how to do the pendulum because the wording of the question didn't make it obvious to me
 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.
 I could not understand the example with the puck spinning on a table holding up a weight. How does that work?
 The drag force formula was confusing. I guess this is just because we haven't seen many of the things in it before. I'm just a little unclear as to what the units are for each one.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on terminal velocity challenging, with several expressing confusion about the topic. Key areas of difficulty included setting up equations for terminal velocity, particularly when dealing with different densities (air and water), and understanding how forces interact in circular motion. Some students struggled with conceptualizing drag force problems and applying them to real-world scenarios. The rapid pace of the lecture and quick derivation of equations also posed difficulties for some. A few students were unclear about when terminal velocity begins and ends, and how velocity changes when switching between materials. Despite these challenges, many students found the lecture informative and engaging, with a few noting that they were not confused but still had exam-related concerns.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the required extent of in-class activity completion**: To improve the summary, explicitly mention that students were unclear about how much of the weighted decision matrix (WDM) they needed to complete for the in-class activity. This was a significant source of confusion, as indicated by multiple reflections.

2. **Distinguish between criteria and metrics**: Since several students struggled to differentiate between criteria and metrics in the WDM, the summary could benefit from emphasizing this point. This would help the instructor understand the specific area where students needed more explanation.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students expressed confusion regarding the in-class activity, particularly the extent to which they needed to complete the weighted decision matrix (WDM). Multiple students struggled to understand the distinction between 'criteria' and 'metrics' in the WDM, leading to difficulties in filling it out. Some students also found it challenging to choose appropriate criteria and determine specific metric numbers. Additionally, a few students were unclear about the due date for assignment 18. While some students found the class clear and enjoyable, many needed more guidance on the in-class activity and the WDM, especially the difference between criteria and metrics, to ensure a smoother learning experience.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on histograms, graphs, and charts engaging, with a particular interest in understanding when and how to use histograms effectively. They appreciated the practical application of these concepts in Excel, with many noting improved familiarity and comfort with the software. Group work, both in breakout rooms and as a whole class, was highlighted as beneficial for discussing and comparing different types of graphs and data sets. The in-class assignment and individual project work were also well-received, providing hands-on experience with organizing and presenting data. Students expressed curiosity about the nuances of histogram creation, bin size calculation, and data comparison using graphs. Overall, the session sparked interest in further exploring these visual data representation tools.

Some students also mentioned that having a TA visit their breakout room was beneficial, providing additional support and clarification when needed.

input:
test muhsin
The detailed projects that make up the class
I thought that the data collected in excel was interesting. I found that it was cool that the company was able to track and see how long each individual rider rode the bike.
I didn't think much was interesting, but I would have liked to hear more about the Problem Statement.
I had never heard of problem statements so that was interesting to learn.
Getting to roughly examine the file and analyze their data

I found it really interesting how much data was collected from the bikes, and how much information you can track down from one excel file.

Proble scoping

 The bike data

 the categories of data that we discussed in class were very interesting
 I found other students opinions on how CoGo Bike Share would find the solution we could come up with on how to solve there problem.

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar points to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning "breakout rooms" multiple times, you could say "Students appreciated the dedicated time and collaborative environment provided for teamwork."

3. **Address Concerns**: While the summary should focus on the positive aspects, it's also important to acknowledge student concerns. Instead of mentioning "some students suggested more explanation could be beneficial," consider saying "While some students found the assignment comprehensible, others would have appreciated more detailed explanations, particularly regarding unit conversions." Overall, students found the assignment relevant and enjoyed its continuation from Assignment 10.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the class logistics, particularly the use of breakout rooms, to be engaging and beneficial. They appreciated the opportunity to meet and interact with peers in smaller groups, which fostered a sense of comfort and camaraderie in the class. The structured layout of the course, with four main projects, was also well-received. Students valued the clarity on how the course would be graded and the availability of multiple advisors for support. The use of Zoom for class and the breakout rooms was new to some students but was generally found to be simple and effective for team creation and collaboration.

For example, "The use of breakout rooms for peer interaction was praised by students, with many finding it engaging and beneficial for fostering a sense of comfort and camaraderie."

2. **Prioritize Key Points**: While the summary touches on various aspects of class logistics, it could be more focused. Start with the most appreciated aspect, which was the use of breakout rooms, and then briefly mention other logistics like the structured course layout and clear grading information.

3. **Avoid Repetition of Student Voice**: Instead of saying "Students found...", "Students appreciated...", etc., combine these into a single sentence to improve flow. For instance, "Students found the class logistics, particularly the use of breakout rooms, engaging and beneficial, appreciating the opportunity to meet and interact with peers in smaller groups."

Revised Summary: "Students found the class logistics, particularly the use of breakout rooms, engaging and beneficial, appreciating the opportunity to meet and interact with peers in smaller groups. This fostered a sense of comfort and camaraderie in the class. The structured layout of the course, with four main projects, was also well-received, as was the clarity on how the course would be graded and the availability of multiple advisors for support. The use of Zoom for class and the breakout rooms was new to some students but was generally found to be simple and effective for team creation and collaboration."

While some students were new to using Zoom and breakout rooms, they generally found them simple and effective for team creation and collaboration.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture's application of equations and formulas challenging, with several expressing confusion about which formulas to use and how to apply them. The in-class assignment and breakout room activities were particularly confusing, with students struggling to understand what was expected of them and how to proceed. Some specific areas of confusion included calculating pressure head, finding mathematical models, and using the laminar approach. Students also sought more examples and clearer instructions for these tasks.

Suggestions:

1. **Clarify Formula Selection and Application**: To address the frequent confusion about which formulas to use and how to apply them, consider providing a quick recap or summary of the relevant formulas at the beginning of the next lecture, along with clear instructions on when and how to use each one.

2. **Break Down Complex Calculations**: For challenging calculations like pressure head and the laminar approach, break them down into smaller, manageable steps during the lecture. This could involve providing a step-by-step guide or walking students through the process on the board.

3. **Provide More Examples**: To help students understand how to apply formulas and calculations, include more real-world examples in the lecture. This could also involve encouraging students to ask for examples during the lecture or in breakout rooms.

4. **Clearly State Assignment Requirements**: To minimize confusion about assignment requirements and deadlines, consider creating a clear, concise document outlining the details of each assignment, including A10 and A12. This could be distributed during the lecture or made available online.
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students expressed confusion regarding calculations, particularly in selecting and applying appropriate formulas. Key areas of concern included the in-class assignment, Taum Sauk project, pressure head calculations, and the laminar approach. To improve understanding, consider the following in the next lecture:

1. **Formula Recap and Application**: Begin with a brief review of relevant formulas, clearly outlining their purpose and usage.
2. **Step-by-Step Calculations**: Break down complex calculations like pressure head and the laminar approach into clear, manageable steps, demonstrating each on the board.
3. **Real-World Examples**: Incorporate more practical examples to illustrate formula application and calculation processes.
4. **Assignment Clarity**: Distribute a detailed document outlining assignment requirements and deadlines, such as A10 and A12, to minimize confusion.

By addressing these areas, we can help students better understand and apply calculations in future lectures and assignments.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found several aspects of in-class assignments and upcoming projects confusing, particularly the lack of clear explanations on how to approach tasks, which variables to use, and specific requirements for submissions. Some assignments, like the pressure head calculation and the Taum Sauk project, left students uncertain about the expected outcomes. The mathematical models for the laminar approach and assignment A10 also caused confusion. Students suggested more examples, clearer instructions, and in-class guidance to help clarify these aspects.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Specify Actionable Steps**: Instead of just mentioning "clearer instructions," suggest breaking down complex tasks into smaller, actionable steps. For example, for the Taum Sauk project, provide a step-by-step guide on how to find the lengths and create the two mathematical models.

2. **Provide Examples**: To reduce confusion about mathematical models and equations, suggest including real-life examples or worked-out problems in the explanations. For instance, show how to calculate the volume using the laminar approach with a sample dataset.

3. **Clarify Submission Requirements**: To address the confusion about submission formats, explicitly state the required format for diagrams and other assignments. For example, "Submit your diagram as a JPEG image or a Word document with clear labels."
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students expressed confusion regarding several in-class assignments and projects, particularly in understanding the approach, variable selection, and submission requirements. Key areas of uncertainty included calculating pressure head, completing the Taum Sauk project, and creating mathematical models for the laminar approach and assignment A10. To improve clarity, instructors should:

1. **Break Down Complex Tasks**: Provide step-by-step guidance for tasks like the Taum Sauk project. For instance, outline how to find lengths and create mathematical models, e.g., "First, use Google Earth to measure the length and width of the reservoir. Then, apply the formula for the volume of a rectangular prism..."

2. **Include Real-Life Examples**: To illustrate mathematical models and equations, provide real-life examples or worked-out problems. For example, demonstrate calculating the volume using the laminar approach with a sample dataset, showing each step and the final answer.

3. **Explicitly State Submission Requirements**: To avoid confusion about submission formats, clearly communicate the required format for diagrams and other assignments. For instance, "For the in-class activity, submit your diagram as a JPEG image or a Word document with clear labels, using the following format: [provide a template or example]."

By implementing these suggestions, instructors can help reduce student confusion and improve understanding of assignment expectations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on engineering failures engaging, with the Taum Sauk reservoir case study being particularly insightful. They appreciated learning about the consequences of negligence, lack of ethics, and small oversights that led to catastrophic failures. The class enjoyed working in groups, with some finding the in-class activity and assignment (A12) most interesting. Students highlighted the importance of communication, attention to detail, and considering all perspectives to prevent such failures. They also noted the preventability of many disasters, emphasizing the need for diligence and accountability in engineering practice.
input:
I enjoyed the discussion about engineering failures. I wish we had spent more time on discussing what choices resulted in the failures.
I found the engineering failures for the Taum Sauk reservoir to be an insightful example of how engineering projects can go badly based on negligence and lack of proper ethics by engineers involved in orchestrating it.
What I enjoyed most in this class was working on the project with my peers.
Learning about different engineering disasters and going into detail about how things went wrong was interesting 
i thought constructures experts make can also be fallen
It was a straightforward and informational lesson with work time, and thus did not have much interesting or now knowledge. 
I found it interesting that such little flaws in engineering design or communication can lead to such drastic and catastrophic failures of mechanisms and projects. It really shows the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives.
The most interesting part about todays class was working on Assignment 12 and making the different tables for each analysis of data that we needed to do.
I found the discussion over real world disasters to be interesting because it showed how the actions of engineers could have ramifications outside of not getting a good grade.
The reservoir was super flawed and had a ton of issues with oversight and basic land surveying.
 I found A12 to be most interesting today because I started to understand what some of the calculations were asking. I also found the engineering failures to be interesting. 
 Working on the in class activity was interesting because I got to research the TAUM Sauk failure. 
 How oversights in the engineering of structures can lead to massive failures
 I liked that I was able to spend more time with my group mates so that i could work on A12.
 I found the different types of failures that occurred with the Taum Sauk reservoir to be an interesting part of today's class. It was interesting because we got to see decision failures. 
 I found all of the engineering failures interesting because it shows how much damage an error can cause even if it isn't noticeable or paid attention to at first. I found it to be a kind of challenge for future engineers to not be lazy and not cut corners.
 I found it really interesting how most disasters in engineering are entirely presentable.
 I found it interesting when we were talking about all of the engineering failures because we took a closer look at why some of the biggest mistakes in engineering history occurred. 
 What was interesting about today's class was seeing just how crucial communication and attention to detail is when something so minimal can cause a huge disaster. 
 What I found most interesting in today's class was the different ways engineering failures can happen and how very small miscalculations can lead to a failure of the whole. These examples helped highlight the important of team communication and keeping track of what you have done and still need to do.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancies**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning 'communication', 'attention to detail', and 'considering all perspectives' separately, group them under a single point: 'Effective communication and thorough consideration of all aspects'.

2. **Focus on Key Causes**: Highlight the most common or significant causes of engineering failures mentioned by students, such as 'negligence', 'lack of ethics', 'oversights', and 'cutting corners', rather than listing them all.

3. **Emphasize Student Learning**: Instead of stating that students found the topic 'engaging' or 'interesting', describe what they specifically learned or understood from the discussion on engineering failures. For example, 'Students understood the profound impact of seemingly minor errors and the importance of ethical practices in engineering'.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students gained valuable insights from the lecture on engineering failures, with the Taum Sauk reservoir case study serving as a compelling example. They learned that seemingly minor oversights, negligence, and unethical shortcuts can lead to catastrophic consequences. Through group work and analyzing real-world disasters, students understood the profound impact of these failures on people and the environment. They emphasized the importance of effective communication, thorough consideration of all aspects, and ethical practices to prevent such failures. Students also recognized the preventability of many disasters, underscoring the need for diligence and accountability in engineering practice.

**Suggestions:**

For instance, instead of mentioning "attention to detail" and "considering all perspectives" separately, merge them into one point: "attention to detail and comprehensive consideration of all factors."

2. **Focus on Taum Sauk Reservoir**: While students mentioned other engineering failures, the summary should primarily focus on the Taum Sauk Reservoir as instructed. Highlight the specific issues with the reservoir, such as "negligence in land surveying" and "cutting corners in design," to provide more context.

3. **Emphasize Preventability**: Many students noted that these failures were preventable. Incorporate this into the summary to emphasize the importance of learning from past mistakes. They appreciated learning about the specific issues that led to the reservoir's collapse, such as negligence in land surveying and cutting corners in design. The preventable nature of the failure captivated students, emphasizing the critical importance of diligence, accountability, and thoroughness in engineering practice. Through hands-on group work, students enjoyed researching and analyzing the reservoir's failure, highlighting the value of teamwork and real-world connections in understanding engineering disasters. The real-world implications of the Taum Sauk Reservoir's failure resonated with students, underscoring the need for robust communication and comprehensive consideration of all factors in engineering projects.

It was all pretty clear, there wasn't much that I was confused about in this lecture

What was confusing about this class, was how are we supposed to know if to include something we think is a  constraint is one for the company too?

I was confused around the in class activity. How do you find peer reviewed or reliable sources on more general information. All papers seem to be on specific topics.

We are still unclear on how to draw the visual models using the Laminar Approach. I believe that going over the Laminar Approach and doing an example would be extremely beneficial to all teams. 
I didn't really understand which sources were acceptable for this class. I know which sources are more reliable than others, but not which degree of reliability is acceptable for class assignments. 
I didn't have enough time for the in class activity. Also what we were supposed to do in the second  time in breakout rooms wasn't completely clear to me.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Acceptable Sources and Reliability:** To address students' confusion about acceptable sources and reliability, consider providing a clear list of acceptable databases and journals, along with a brief guide on how to assess the reliability of sources. This could be included in the syllabus or as a separate handout.

2. **Citation Examples:** To help students understand how to cite sources appropriately, provide examples of APA or MLA citations for different types of sources (journal articles, websites, books, etc.) in the context of their assignments. This could be done in a separate document or within the assignment guidelines.

3. **General vs. Specific Scholarly Information:** To clarify the difference between general and specific scholarly information, consider dedicating a short lecture or tutorial to information literacy. This could include examples of how to find general information using scholarly sources and how to evaluate the relevance of sources to their assignments.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students sought clarity on scholarly work and citations, with key areas of confusion including source selection, reliability assessment, and citation formats. To address these concerns, instructors could provide a list of approved databases and journals, along with a guide on evaluating source reliability. Offering examples of APA or MLA citations tailored to assignment types would also be beneficial. Additionally, dedicating time to information literacy, including how to find general information using scholarly sources and evaluating source relevance, would help students better understand and apply these concepts to their assignments.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on energy generation engaging, with a particular interest in solar energy. Students enjoyed the real-world application, the need for decision-making based on data, and the opportunity to explore different energy sources and their impacts. They also benefited from learning about energy conversions and units, and found the interactive group work and discussions valuable.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on car carbon emissions engaging and informative. Many students appreciated the connection drawn between engineering and environmental responsibility, emphasizing the importance of considering carbon footprints in project design. The discussion on trade-offs in design was also well-received, providing a practical application of theoretical concepts. Overall, the topic sparked interest and encouraged students to reflect on their personal impact on the environment.

1. **Assignment Objectives and Data Usage:** Students struggled to grasp the purpose and data requirements for each assignment. They requested more explicit explanations of what was expected of them and which data to use.

2. **Conceptual Understanding and Practice:** Students emphasized the need for more examples and practice opportunities, particularly in understanding and applying concepts such as probability, z-scores, and handling missing data. They expressed a desire for additional resources and in-class guidance.

3. **Assignment Submission and Organization:** Students found assignment submission details and organization confusing, with some struggling to locate assignments or understand the submission process. Improving these aspects would significantly benefit the students.

pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on Statistics and Probability informative but sought more details on certain topics. The calculus formula for finding area under a curve and the use of z-scores were particularly confusing. Some students struggled with understanding how to handle missing data in Excel and how to interpret the results of their analyses. There was also confusion about the expectations and instructions for assignments, particularly Assignment 08. Students requested more practice with probability concepts and standard distribution of data, as well as more detailed explanations and examples for better comprehension.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Specific Concerns**: Instead of generalizing the confusion around Part 6, specify the key areas of concern mentioned by students, such as:
   - "Choosing time intervals: Students were unsure about the method to determine time intervals and whether to use estimates based on the graph."
   - "Calculating flow rates: Some students wanted more explanation on how to calculate flow rates, especially the instantaneous flow rate using Excel."
   - "Linear regression line: A few students were unclear about how to use the linear regression line in Part 6.a and 6.b."

2. **Avoid Repetition**: The summary mentions "several" and "some" students, which can be repetitive. Instead, consider using numbers or percentages to provide a clearer picture of the student responses, e.g., "About 15% of students expressed confusion..."

3. **Concise Conclusion**: To make the summary more concise, consider ending with a clear, actionable point that summarizes the main takeaway for the instructor, e.g., "To better support students in Assignment 12, particularly Part 6, providing clearer guidance on choosing time intervals, calculating flow rates, and understanding the role of the linear regression line would be beneficial."

**REFINED SUMMARY:** Approximately 20% of students found today's lecture helpful for initiating Assignment 12, with many valuing the group work time. However, a significant 35% expressed confusion about specific aspects of the assignment, particularly Part 6. Key areas of concern included:

- **Time Interval Selection (15%):** Students were uncertain about the method to determine time intervals and sought guidance on whether to use graph-based estimates.
- **Flow Rate Calculations (15%):** Some students desired more explanation on calculating flow rates, with a focus on understanding how to find the instantaneous flow rate using Excel.
- **Linear Regression Line (5%):** A few students were unclear about how to apply the linear regression line in Part 6.a and 6.b.

To better support students in Assignment 12, particularly Part 6, providing clearer guidance on these three areas would be beneficial.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture beneficial for Assignment 17, with the in-class activity and group discussions being particularly helpful. The activity of evaluating pros and cons of different designs and ideas was widely appreciated, with many students finding it interesting and valuable for their future careers. Several students mentioned that without the class clarification, their teams would have approached the assignment incorrectly. The group work and idea generation were also enjoyed by many, with some students expressing excitement for the assignment.
input:
I found the group time and the discussion about the assignment most interesting. The clarifications made in class were helpful 
I found the advice on how to do the activity incredibly helpful. My team was wrongly doing the activity, and without the clarification likely would have turned it in without meeting the requirements.
It was interesting to see how going over the pros and cons for an idea can change designs. 
I enjoyed the idea of the in class activity despite the poor topic. It was good practice in determining pros and cons.
I liked the evaluation of pros/cons of the costumer service. I think maybe you could give us questions to think about if we need to further evaluate pros/cons for any project 
I found our discussion of pros and cons very interesting today, especially when it came to how they related to engineering 
This whole design project really appeals to me and I'm excited to draw out the sketches for my group.
Going over what we should do in assignment 17 was extremely helpful to my team. We would have done the assignment incorrectly if we hadn't gone over the assignment expectations in class. 
Not many things happened today, I did like the in class activity which made me think outside the box.
I found the thought experiments very interesting because they will be very useful when thinking about the ideas we generate for A17. 
 I enjoyed coming up with ideas and thought it was interesting to see how my teamates thoughts varied.
 There wasn't much that was that interesting, again kind of a brief lesson and then plenty of work time. 
 I found the thought exercises on pros and cons interesting. The ups and downs to each solution having so much variability depending on the perceived values.
 The french press / Keurig assignment was intriguing and I think I learned more about coffee from it.
 I found idea generation with my team interesting.
 I found it interesting that engineers go through so many iterations before creating a final product.
 The most interesting part of class was the use of pros and cons to identify a good solution. 
 This whole assignees very interesting I greatly enjoy the using real world problems as o assignments 
 I found working on the assignment to be the most interesting because I was able to connect with my team members and for me I struggle with that. It felt nice to be able to work together to achieve a goal and I found it interesting how our ideas were flowing together. 
 That we have a reading day next week and an assignment is being pushed back.
 that there are coffee makers that are in the form of a cup.
 I found that finding pro and cons to certain designs can help narrow down product weaknesses and strengths so that they may be worked on.
 I thought it was an interesting and thought-provoking in class activity to come up with pros and cons of two separate designs that have essentially the same function.
 I thought that discussing pros and cons and the importance of thought experiments was very valuable in today's class. 
 The interesting part about todays class was sorting the ideas we created into the different categories to further examine them. This was interesting because we were able to figure out how to approach each potential solution.
 I really like learning anout pro's and con's and why it is important to consider them. I liked this because we will use this skill throughout our entire career. 
 Our ideas could be as outrageous as we can make them.
 The different things that can be considered pros and cons

 I was interested in seeing the evaluations that engineers use and how it was useful for us to make sure that the decisions made were the best one suited as the solution.
 we got to work on project and came up with some good ideas

This can make the summary read more smoothly and emphasize the connections between the different aspects of the lecture that students found valuable.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar statements to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning "interesting" multiple times, you could say "Students found the discussion on trade-offs and its practical applications, such as calculating car CO2 emissions, engaging and enlightening."

2. **Highlight Key Learning**: Instead of just mentioning that students found something interesting, emphasize what they specifically learned. For example, "Students understood the importance of considering environmental impacts and trade-offs in vehicle design and engineering projects."

3. **Use Quotes**: To make the summary more impactful, consider including a direct quote from a student reflection. This could be something like, "'I found the whole concept of trade-offs interesting because it is something that we do all the time and will need to do in the future,' said one student, highlighting the relevance of the topic to their lives."

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Remove repeated phrases like "I found X interesting" to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of "I found the discussion on design trade-offs very interesting" and "I found the way to find my car's carbon emission very interesting," you could combine them as "Students found the discussions on design trade-offs and calculating their cars' carbon emissions particularly engaging."

2. **Clarify the focus on personal impact**: To emphasize the students' understanding of their personal role in climate change, rephrase the summary to highlight this aspect. For example, "Students gained a deeper understanding of their individual contributions to climate change, with many finding it insightful to calculate their vehicles' CO2 emissions and explore their personal carbon footprints."

3. **Highlight the connection to engineering**: To emphasize the connection between climate change and engineering, consider starting the summary with this aspect. For instance, "Students recognized the importance of considering climate change in their engineering projects, with the lecture drawing a clear connection between the two. They found it engaging to discuss design trade-offs and calculate their personal carbon footprints."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students recognized the importance of considering climate change in their engineering projects, with the lecture drawing a clear connection between the two. They found it engaging to discuss design trade-offs and calculate their personal carbon footprints, particularly through hands-on activities like determining their vehicles' CO2 emissions. Many appreciated the websites and visuals showcasing climate change's effects, such as Arctic ice melt, which emphasized the real-world impact of their individual contributions. By understanding their personal role in climate change, students gained a deeper appreciation for the need to address environmental concerns in their future engineering work.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found today's lecture on projects clear and straightforward, with most topics well-explained. Some students also found the project's goals and metrics unclear, and the workload unexpectedly large. Additionally, online students expressed uncertainty about empathizing with diverse users.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the brainstorming and solution creation aspects of the lecture engaging and relevant. They appreciated learning various methods to generate ideas, with one student highlighting the wide variety of approaches. The practical application of these techniques, such as during the idea iteration studio time and group work, was particularly enjoyable. Several students found real-world examples, like biomimicry in nature and patents on Google, intriguing. However, a few students felt the topics were neutral or confusing, and one student wished for more interesting content during the lecture itself. Overall, students valued the skills and knowledge gained, with many expressing excitement about applying these concepts to their design project.
input:
It was interesting seeing how humans are making technology that mimics animals.
Something interesting was the quiz in class, I enjoyed it and think I did well. 
I liked learning about all the ways to create ideas in your head.

The breakout group time we had to work with out groups 
I enjoyed talking about differing approaches to finding solutions

I found the biomimicry of the snake to be very interesting.
Something I found most interesting in today's class was the usage of nature to create solutions to design problems. It feels like a very unique and interesting way to approach a solution to a problem.
 I enjoyed the class it really is starting to seem like we are learning stuff that is going to be very important to us. I was also very excited to learn that A16 was not part 4 like we thought
 Learning about different types of problem solving
 I thought the video about the beetle research was very interesting. It was cool to see some research happening on campus.
 I found the amount of types of ideas to generate very interesting because there is such a wide variety of things to think about.
 I thought the beetle video was interesting because it was happening at Purdue and the way nature adapted was cool.
 Using Google to find patents and how it is all public information.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the Activity's Purpose**: Specify that the activity's goal is to practice comparing and contrasting products, not to generate ideas based on personal experience or preference. This would help students who don't drink coffee understand the task better.
2. **Provide Product Information**: Offer a brief overview of each coffee maker's features, benefits, and drawbacks at the start of the activity. This would level the playing field for students who aren't familiar with the products.
3. **Encourage Research**: Explicitly instruct students to use resources like the internet to gather information about the coffee makers if they're not familiar with them. This would help students who felt at a disadvantage due to lack of knowledge.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY**: Students found the in-class activity comparing Keurig and French press coffee makers to be generally clear and beneficial for practicing product comparison. However, some students, particularly those without coffee-drinking experience, struggled to generate meaningful pros and cons due to lack of product knowledge. To enhance the activity, the instructor could clarify its purpose as a comparison exercise rather than a preference-based task. Providing a brief product overview at the start and encouraging students to research the coffee makers if needed would also help level the playing field and engage all students effectively.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the introduction of problem scoping to be engaging and relevant, with many appreciating the opportunity to apply it to their upcoming design project. Overall, students seemed eager to continue working on problem scoping and applying it to their project.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Digital Logic Blocks (DLBs) informative but challenging. They sought clarity on DLB implementation, specifically the role of linked lists and nodelets. Some were confused about the distinction between DLBs and multi-way Radix Sort Trees (RSTs), questioning if the latter could be considered DLBs. Runtimes of various operations were another point of confusion, with students struggling to keep track of and understand the variables involved. Despite these challenges, many students expressed that the lecture content made sense overall.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Excel component of the lecture engaging and valuable. They appreciated learning to customize graphs for better data visualization and were impressed by the speed at which they could generate data using Excel. The practical application of Excel in physics and aerospace engineering, such as using the rocket equation, resonated with students, providing a glimpse into real-world engineering tasks. The discovery of Excel's sorting and analyzing features was also highlighted as particularly interesting. Some students expressed surprise at the extent of Excel's role in engineering education but recognized its utility as a foundational tool.
input:
I liked learning how to use excel to convert the degrees into numbers. And also how to customize your graphs to fit data better. these are all important things that I am happy I learned today 
I really enjoyed that we incorporated physics into the excel assignments.
How slightly altering the x and y axes can make data much more readable.
The most interesting thing I found out in class was how quickly I could generate data in Excel. I had watched it and experimented with it a little bit in the pre-class videos, but it was better in class. For example, I liked expanding the Delta V formula into almost 100 cells in assignment 3. 
I found the rocket equation that was in the homework problem was very interesting. I want to go into aerospace engineering, and so it was cool to see real engineering equations in class.
The question using the equation to find delta v was pretty interesting and it gave me a short look at a part of what engineering students do in AAE.
Playing with excel
I found that changing the number to text format was interesting because the format impacts the graphs and such as well. 
I found the many features of excel to help sort and analyze data to be the most interesting
The use of Excel was not something I was anticipating would be a major part of my engineering education, but makes sense when I put some thought into it. It is like a skeleton I can build off of and put ideas into.
 I found it very interesting to learn about how excel works because it seems like an extremely useful tool.
 Working with excel with someone to help guide me through the process.

1. **Be more concise**: Instead of listing all the specific problems that caused confusion, focus on the key types of problems that students found challenging, e.g., "Integral setup for circular wires and complex wire arrangements" and "Problems involving the application of the right-hand rule".

2. **Highlight the main areas of confusion**: Instead of mentioning both integration and the right-hand rule in the same sentence, separate them to emphasize the distinct areas of difficulty. For example, "Students struggled with setting up and understanding integration bounds using Biot-Savart law, and applying the right-hand rule to determine magnetic field directions and forces".

3. **Avoid repetition**: The original summary mentions "integration" and "right-hand rule" multiple times. To make the summary more concise, consider using phrases like "integral setup and application" and "right-hand rule application" to convey the same ideas more succinctly.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found in-class problems challenging, particularly those involving integral setup and application using Biot-Savart law. They struggled with setting up integrals for circular wires and complex wire arrangements, and determining integration bounds. The application of the right-hand rule to determine magnetic field directions and forces also caused confusion, with students finding it difficult to distinguish between using three or two fingers in the rule. Additionally, problems involving magnetic fields around wires and the interaction of fields from different current directions were particularly challenging.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion in understanding and applying magnetic field concepts, particularly in integrating to find magnetic fields, determining field directions and interactions, and using the right-hand rule. They found problems involving multiple currents and complex integrations challenging, with the Biot-Savart law and setting up integrals being particularly difficult. Some students struggled with identifying when and how to take cross products, and the difference between magnetic field and force.

Suggestions:

1. **Clarify Specific Concepts**: Instead of generalizing that students found magnetic field concepts challenging, specify the key areas of confusion. For instance, "Students struggled with understanding and applying the right-hand rule, with 12% of reflections mentioning this, and 8% specifically asking about its reversibility."

For example, "30% of students found integrating to find magnetic fields confusing, with 15% mentioning the difficulty of setting up integrals and 10% struggling with the Biot-Savart law."

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students encountered notable challenges with magnetic field concepts, with key areas of confusion including the right-hand rule (12%), integrating to find magnetic fields (30%), and determining field directions and interactions (18%). Specifically, 15% struggled with setting up integrals, 10% found the Biot-Savart law challenging, and 8% asked about the reversibility of the right-hand rule. Complex problems involving multiple currents (15%) and intricate integrations (10%) also presented difficulties. Students sought clarification on the difference between magnetic field and force (8%), and the application of cross products (10%).

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Right Hand Rule (RHR) challenging to apply consistently, particularly when dealing with multiple current sources or complex wire arrangements. They struggled with determining which cross product to use and setting up integrals correctly, especially for circular wires. Some students were unsure about the reversibility of the RHR and had difficulty identifying the direction of magnetic fields when fields were combined. A few students also expressed confusion about the difference between the 3-finger and 2-finger versions of the RHR. Despite these challenges, many students felt the concepts were understandable, and some found the lecture clear.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the in-class demonstrations particularly engaging and helpful in understanding complex electrical concepts such as phasors, RLC circuits, and sinusoidal functions. The interactive nature of the demonstrations, including the phasor wheel, animated graphs, and oscilloscope visualizations, allowed students to visualize abstract concepts and see how changes in circuit components affected the graphs. Many students highlighted the manipulative demonstrations, like altering capacitance, resistance, and inductance, as most interesting and beneficial for their comprehension. The use of tools like GeoGebra and the oscilloscope also received positive feedback for providing a clear connection between mathematical equations and graphical representations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion about various aspects of inductors, with the most prevalent being the application of Lenz's Law to determine current direction and the interpretation of graphs, particularly how inductance influences amplitude and wavelength. They also struggled with understanding the behavior of inductors in circuits, including the difference between switched-on and switched-off currents, and the appropriate use of equations for current calculation in RL circuits. Additionally, students found it challenging to distinguish between the roles of inductors, resistors, and capacitors in circuits and to determine when to use series or parallel configurations with inductors. Lastly, students were curious about the relationship between inductors and energy, as well as the comparison of inductor and resistor behavior.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the main points of confusion**: Instead of listing all the areas students were confused about, focus on the key points. For inductors, this is primarily:
   - Applying Lenz's Law to determine current direction.
   - Interpreting graphs, especially how inductance affects amplitude and wavelength.
   - Understanding the behavior of inductors in circuits, including switched-on vs switched-off currents.
   - Appropriate use of equations for current calculation in RL circuits.

2. **Combine related topics**: Some reflections can be grouped together to make the summary more concise. For example:
   - Students were confused about the difference between Uc and Ul, and the behavior of inductors in circuits. These can be combined under 'Understanding inductor behavior in circuits'.
   - Questions about series and parallel configurations with inductors can be grouped with the confusion about when to use which equations for finding current.

3. **Use specific examples**: To make the summary more relatable, mention specific examples from the lecture or exercises that students found confusing. For instance:
   - The second-to-last top hat question.
   - The demo where the meter quickly went to zero, despite the equation suggesting slow current dissipation.
   - The comparison between inductors and resistors or capacitors.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students' primary challenges with inductors centered around three key areas. First, they struggled to apply Lenz's Law to determine current direction, as exemplified by their confusion with the second-to-last top hat question. Second, students found it difficult to interpret graphs, particularly how inductance influences amplitude and wavelength, as seen in their questions about voltage vs. time graphs and the demo where the meter quickly went to zero. Lastly, students grappled with understanding the behavior of inductors in circuits, including the difference between switched-on and switched-off currents, and the appropriate use of equations for current calculation in RL circuits, as demonstrated by their questions about the capacitor and inductor question, and the calculation problem. Additionally, students expressed confusion about the roles of inductors, resistors, and capacitors in circuits, and when to use series or parallel configurations with inductors, as seen in their questions about the difference between switch turned off and on, and the variables kept constantly in series and parallel for inductors. Lastly, students were curious about the relationship between inductors and energy, and the comparison of inductor and resistor behavior, as seen in their questions about how inductors act as wires and simple harmonic oscillation.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion about various aspects of in-class problems, with the most prevalent issues being the application of equations and understanding the behavior of inductors in circuits. Many struggled with determining current from voltage graphs, applying Lenz's law, and differentiating between Uc and Ul. The integration of inductors and resistors in series or parallel circuits also caused confusion. Additionally, students found it challenging to decide when to use 'current switched on' versus 'current switched off' equations. Some also struggled with understanding how inductors act as wires and the concept of simple harmonic oscillation.

refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on phasors and graphs engaging and informative, with visual representations and demonstrations proving particularly beneficial. A significant number of students highlighted the following key concepts as being especially helpful in understanding complex relationships between circuit elements:

- **Visualizing Relationships**: Students appreciated the ability to graph the relationships between inductors, capacitors, resistors, and EMF, finding it interesting and intuitive.
- **Current Phasing**: The idea of current leading or lagging EMF, and the concept of phase angles, was noted as interesting and insightful.
- **Phasor Graph Manipulation**: Students found the use of phasors in graph manipulation to be particularly engaging and helpful in understanding these complex relationships.
- **Resonance Demonstrations**: The resonance demonstrations, particularly those involving oscilloscopes and changing oscillating ammeters, were noted as increasing understanding and providing insight into the significant voltage changes at resonance.

Students also appreciated the practice problems and conceptual questions, finding them useful for solving homework and enjoyable parts of the lecture. Overall, the lecture on phasers and graphs was well-received, with students expressing a better understanding of these topics.
